post_text:
I've been dreaming about hosting a musician's wellness retreat for a couple years, this is the year I want to launch... Problem is $ and what musicians find valuable. So many times we live in broke mindset, but what if spending $$ could change your life and what you command in performance, self confidence and my realm: prevent and overcome injury for yourself (and maybe your whole band/crew?) 

I struggle with it myself, until I paid $4k for a 6 night stay in the Waldorf Astoria Washington DC and $12k for a new flute (finally!) and it was WORTH EVERY PENNY!

But musicians are broke, right?

No.

You always find the money for the things you want, whether it's a new instrument or a good night's sleep .

I have a LOT of ideas but before I go into it, what would make you say YES!!! Immediately yes!  To a wellness retreat (especially if it was catered specifically to musicians?)

Feel free to DM if you would prefer.

comments.text: Going to my weekly Bluegrass jam with my <$1000 mandolin or guitar keeps my cup full. ðŸ˜Ž

post_text:
Looking for advice on acquired scoliosis in a 17 yo severe TBI patient. Heâ€™s generally low tone through the trunk, and has some trace activation of flexors and extensors, but nothing consistent and nothing throughout the full range of movement. 
We do all of the developmental postures, pool therapy, isometrics and PNF techniques and rolling. We use NMES (but havenâ€™t on the trunk?) Iâ€™ve worked with family on positioning in bed, and in the wc. Just got a new wc within the last year, with trunk support, but we may look at adjusting it. 
Any ideas on what else we could do to stop the progression of scoliosis? Do you think an assessment with a Schroth therapist would be beneficial, if he does not consistently follow commands? If so any recommendations in Phoenix AZ?

Thanks for any advice!

comments.text:
Katie Blanchard 
SchrothBoss !

https://www.instagram.com/schrothboss?igsh=MXMwbG90OHAycHRwcQ==

Schroth/PSSE is mainly for adolescent idiopathic scoliosis. Neuromuscular scoliosis requires a different approach. The 3dimensional principles might be applicable when designing a wheelchair support. Custom bracing would probably be more beneficial considering the cognitive impairment.

post_text: Can someone tell doctors, assisted livings, nurses, etc that Fox rehab isnâ€™t the only home therapy company in the world?! Anyone notice that this is the only company that patients get referred to?

comments.text:
There is McDonalds... and everyone else. 
There is Starbucks... and everyone else. 

Fox has spent lots of money establishing themselves as the Kleenex of physical therapy. Nobody says "Grab me a fascial tissue." They say grab me a Kleenex. 

So since Fox owns the general home physical therapy space, you can build a presence in the specialty space. You can be the post surgical knee guy or the skin breakdown guy or the ??? guy.

Just go one layer down.

Weighing in after watching this for a while. To compete with Fox you have to be different than Fox, but also donâ€™t be afraid to collaborate with Fox. What can you do to build up your reputation to be â€˜the bestâ€™ option? Quality therapy? Specialty programs? Better/more direct customer service? Market as a locally owned business? Make the most of your smaller scale - get to know the providers and local home health agencies so they know YOU and trust you are the best option for their patients. And reach out to your local fox manager to let them know you can help if there are regions they canâ€™t provide therapy in. I know my local fox regional directors and often refer back and forth if/when we canâ€™t accommodate someone due to waitlist or territory and they do the same for us. We often have patients seeing a Fox PT and a Healthy Aging Physical Therapy OT etc. make friends ..not enemies :)

Needing help or advice on getting medical benefits for employees. I'm a small pediatric private practice in Austin Texas.

I currently need some form of medical benefits for one employee now and for another one starting in January. Does anyone have any thoughts and suggestions on plans or providing a stipend for a healthï¿¼share?

comments.text: I would start with offering supplemental benefits, like accident/injury, hospitalization, short-term disability, major life event. The two big companies that handle this are AFLAC and Unum. I am personally an agent for AFLAC because AFLAC is the only company that covers mental health hospitalization as a hospitalization as well as as For a short term disability due to mental health reasons etc. also, AFLAC is the only supplemental health plan that pays out for hospitalization. As long as you are in the hospital for 18 hours. Every other plan is 24 hours. This may seem like not a big deal but I was actually once hospitalized for 23 hours and I went to submit my claim to Unum and it didnâ€™t qualify but it would have if I had AFLAC. And thatâ€™s $1000 difference.  Otherwise every state is different as far as insurance is concerned for health sharing plans. Otherwise look into QSEHRA (Qualified Small Employer Health Reimbursement Arrangement)
I have a local friend who does the is for companies. I can message you his info if you want.

post_text:
Iâ€™m considering switching from OP to HH to have more time to work on my side gig. 

Iâ€™m wondering if there is anyone else that took this route and have any tips or advice on taking this path

Thank you

comments.text: Is the side gig in healthcare? How much actual extra time are you needing? I wasnâ€™t attempting to grow a side gig when I tried HH from OP but I fell for the â€œmuch more free timeâ€ or â€œschedule your time offâ€. I just found myself either making up for that time off on another day & as far as free time I found myself working way more from home on documenting then I wanted. & then making calls & scheduling is a whole other headache. Not trying to discourage you just giving my experience on trying HH ðŸ˜…..I lasted two months then went back to OP

I was OP, then had a baby and switched to HH 2 decades ago. Last year I went back to OP, but may eventually wander back into HH for the flexibility and money. I wanted a mental challenge by going back to OP (boy, did I get one!) but also was missing camaraderie as HH is very isolating. OP these days is so much more of a grind, and everyone is so stressed. Our clinic has staggered lunches so fun interactions are minimal. HH can be overwhelming (as any new setting would be), but being one on one is such a blessing. Just know that motivation to improve is often much less in HH; many of those folks are fine to be completely sedentary and never perform an HEP, as long as they can make it from the recliner/bed to the toilet/bsc. Good luck! There are definitely advantages to both settings!

Entrepreneurship is often filled with uncertainties, risks, and countless decisions. While external advice and research are valuable, one of the most important factors for success is the ability to trust yourself.

When you trust yourself, you will notice improvements in each of the following areas:

- Confidence in Decision-Making

- Resilience in the Face of Challenges

- Authenticity and Innovation

- Better Leadership

- Freedom from Over-Reliance on External Validation

- Enhanced Creativity and Problem-Solving

post_text:
Occupational therapist here with 13 years of experience soon to interview for a 3 x 10-hour weekend acute care position.

 (1) In relation to a traditional 40-hour work week, what would you expect the salary to be for this position? Do you feel it should be 75% of a 40-hour work week salary or incentivized with a bit higher salary for the non-traditional schedule? 

(2) What would your concerns be for this schedule? Topics to address during the interview?

Thanks for your time!

comments.text: I thought they made pretty close to a full salary. When I worked in home care we had therapists who worked Friday Saturday Sunday or Saturday Sunday Monday and they made a full, full-time salary.

As a weekend therapist I would ask what the incentive for weekend work is and I would ask how many weekends you are allowed to ask off for. Even as a full time weekday therapist in both acute and home health there is a weekend differential, so I got paid a little bit more for my weekend hours than my weekday hours, so as someone who dedicates all weekends I would expect that as well. 
Benefit would be similar to a nursing schedule, when you take one weekend off you have nearly two weeks of days off with only taking 30 hours PTO. but, like i said, ask how many weekends youâ€™re allowed to ask off for. I worked for a hospital and we had a weekend warrior team, and I think they were allowed 4 weekends for PTO requests. Obviously if something came up we made it work, like family emergency, bereavement, etc. but as requests off they were limited in how many they could ask for in the year. But they got paid a fairly hefty differential, more than just the weekend differential for weekday clinicians. 
Also ask if there is a time commitment, our weekend warriors signed on for a year commitment to the weekend plan. Again, they got paid a nice differential to do it so it was mostly our younger/new grads who would do it for 1-2 years for the extra pay, and then transition to weekday team

post_text:
I have a PT who just became pregnant! Awesome news.

And I am just now realizing Iâ€™ll have to figure out her scheduling with her patients and such.

How the heck do I go about doing that with her current patients? Itâ€™ll be fine with not putting new patients on her schedule but what about her existing patients? 

Because I offer maternity leave for 4-6 weeks. So assuming she takes all of that, I want to plan it out so her patients donâ€™t get dropped.

comments.text:
While pregnant and when my staff became pregnant, I stopped giving evals when they hit around 30-32 weeks if they planned to work until they deliver. They would only see follow-ups and Wellness visits. Start thinking about hiring coverage for her leave if you want to keep the patient census at the same level. Also, know that she may choose to take more leave that would not be paid as a benefit and/or use her sick time depending on how you handle benefits. If so, anticipate that she may be gone for closer to 8-12 weeks. 

Also, think about what her return will look like and how you can support her and think about things such as support to help her navigate the transition to working with children, breastfeeding, etc.
Also, and I donâ€™t meant this rudely, but just ask her, and then keep asking her along the way â¤ï¸

post_text: Question for the foot people- I have a marthon runner that has sharp pain/pinch on the anterior Subtaylor joint.  Slightly limited in posterior mobility, 5 DF.  It almost acts like a small tear, but no click and all testing negative.  Any suggestions?  TIA

comments.text: As a marathon runner and a PT who works with runners- I genuinely emphasize ruling out a stress fracture. Those can get back pretty quickly if they keep running.

I like the recs in the other comments. Iâ€™d also do a trial of a navicular lift taping from the lateral foot, going under the arch and then drawing up on the navicular and medial talus. See if that support reduces the pain from initial contact to foot flat.

full_thread_text:
POST: Question for the foot people- I have a marthon runner that has sharp pain/pinch on the anterior Subtaylor joint.  Slightly limited in posterior mobility, 5 DF.  It almost acts like a small tear, but no click and all testing negative.  Any suggestions?  TIA

COMMENT 1: As a marathon runner and a PT who works with runners- I genuinely emphasize ruling out a stress fracture. Those can get back pretty quickly if they keep running.

COMMENT 2: I like the recs in the other comments. Iâ€™d also do a trial of a navicular lift taping from the lateral foot, going under the arch and then drawing up on the navicular and medial talus. See if that support reduces the pain from initial contact to foot flat.

post_text:
What would be good options for a COTA that wants to be the owner of an OT business?

Since COTAs need an OTR for supervision, co-signing notes, evals/discharges, to write goals, etc.â€¦Iâ€™m struggling with how to get a business going when I donâ€™t have the money to hire an OTR. Not until the business starts making money. How would I navigate that?

Iâ€™m interested in having a mobile OT practice that sees patients throughout the lifespan, & was thinking about taking Medicare, Medicaid, be OON for other insurances, & cash.

Iâ€™m located in Idaho, if that makes a difference.

comments.text:
Iâ€™m a PTA who owns a pelvic therapy clinic. I started by talking to PTs I had already worked with to see who would be willing to do some evals for me. I am a cash clinic so Iâ€™m able to pay well and I have a great working relationship with many PTs. I had a taker and she just works 4-8 hours per month doing evals PRN around her other schedule. I now have a second location with another PT that gives me 4-6 hrs per month. I do all treatments. 
Start networking, be generous as you fiscally can and flexible with schedule and you might be surprised who is open to working for you.

post_text: Looking to hear any experience with using  StemWave in your practice. Both with the company/device itself and with patient results.

comments.text:
I have a StemWave device. It works wonders.  You can use it over prosthesis.  It is a shockwave therapyâ€¦ but when you look into the type of wave they are all slightly different.  StemWave has the highest amplitude sound wave out of all of themâ€¦. Making the cells think they have microtrauma stimulating the healing response. 
Yes itâ€™s loudâ€¦. But you choose the amount of energy you put into the patient.  The pain does not get better worse before it gets better as someone else said.  Most of my patients have a 70-80% pain relief in one visit.  
This has completely changed how I operate my clinic.

Not worth the money.  Poor research to support improvement on anything except plantar fasciitis.  
Pain increases before it decreases.  In my research Iâ€™ve found that you Canâ€™t use on joint replacement because it can loosen the prosthesis. Also can make a partial tears worse.  Itâ€™s loud. Often patients can tolerate whatâ€™s considered the â€˜therapeutic doseâ€™

post_text:
For the love of PT and mental health of all practitioners,
How does one start?!

We recently moved states. 

Interviewing at run-of-the-mill or half-a-notch above low expectations clinics after obtaining the local license, I just feel like walking  up the proverbial downstairs escalator.  

What got me most recently was the answer of a posh 1:1 practice place owner â€œif you maxed out of your 2 weeks of PTO, just take an unpaid day, we understand life happensâ€

3 years out of PT school, an LMT cross-over.  My patients knew and appreciated my touch and my passion to educate them onto their breakaway into strengthening from pain be it a trauma, post-op, or repetitive stress injury. 

I donâ€™t want to be a PT drone anymore, ever. 

How does one start with little to no money down, like individual attention home health sessions, a gig at a gym, a personal acquaintance referral?..

comments.text: I had an AWESOME PTA who I adored. She was amazing with patients and everyone loved her. One day, she walked into my office, handed in her notice, and said she was going to MT school. She has now opened her own place (in her house), treats 5 hours a day/4 days a week and charges $120 an hour. She is killing it! And, she is so happy. Honestly, I probably could have never matched that amount for salary. Not to be digging on myself (she actually gives me credit for building her confidence enough to make the move) but...get creative. If you are still an LMT it's easier to get people to pay cash. You could create an entire niche "All the benefits of massage with the knowledge to help you build strength". Whatever, come up with something more marketable, but you get my point.
Follow your passion. Some start with a table in a car, some start with a corner in a gym. Go to where your people are and do it with passion and youâ€™ll find a way.

post_text:
Is the grass really greener? Is it though, really?
Thatâ€™s what I wrestle with on a daily basis. Iâ€™m currently working full-time in large hospital. Itâ€™s standard corporate healthcare, with all of the usual BS. I like my job, though. I get paid relatively well (or so I think). No weekends, no holidays. My patients love me, and I love them. I am a parent of young kids. I value my time more than anything. I like that I donâ€™t have to think about work when I finally come home at night. And yet, I still struggle with the â€œwhat if?â€â€¦ what if Iâ€™m missing out on something? Would becoming Uncaged and breaking out on my own make me happier? Would it make me lonelier, not constantly being around coworkers? Would it mess with my mental health? Would it steal my time away from my kids? Does anyone regret going out on their own? Iâ€™m sure there are many opinions out there, and maybe this group is inherently biased towards breaking out, but Iâ€™m curious and would love honest feedback.

comments.text: "I value my time more than anything", is what you wrote. My perspective is this - my business is my 3rd child. The nice thing? I have flexibility over my schedule when the first borns need me. The hard part? The 3rd child always needs attention to! ðŸ™‚

Based on everything you said - stay where you are. If/when you start hating your job and you want more schedule flexibility and more control of how you treat your patients in order to eventually get paid more to do less, then branch out. But right nowâ€¦. Stay put my friend! Business is not easy, especially at first. I was lonelier for sure. Iâ€™m eager to get back into a team setting at some point, but would only ever join a primary care practice.

post_text:
**Success happens over nights - not overnight**

It is so easy to get bummed out or to feel like a failure when we see others doing great things in their practices.

Two things:

ðŸ‘‰ I am willing to bet that when you see those wins, the intention is meant to motivate and inspire you.

ðŸ‘‰ The subliminal message in those posts is: "*After a good period of busting my butt, being obedient to the process, and trusting the process, this has been the outcome... and you can do this, too!"*

You know those new music artists that suddenly bust onto the scene? They've actually been working on their craft for years. 

Those public speakers who captivate an audience? They have logged hours honing that skill.

An athlete who can perform a particular move with ease and grace has put in thousands upon thousands of reps to master it.

Clinic owners who are "crushing it" have gone through their own frustrations of rejections.

If you are struggling, then ask: How are you struggling?  Where is the block?

In our experience, it is one of three things:

ðŸ‘‰ Their Identity has not been defined

ðŸ‘‰ They struggle with conversations (due to #1)

ðŸ‘‰ All of the above

"Overnight" success is achieved when we enjoy the journey to getting there.

Keep taking steps.

The UNCAGED team and myself are cheering for you.

If you want to chat, I'm here for you.

Does any unicorn in this group know if animal-assisted therapy under the supervision of a physical therapist is a covered service under medicare? From what Iâ€™ve read it seems like itâ€™s not but skilled PT isâ€¦.and it would be a combo of the two. 

If not, how do I go about finding out? 

Iâ€™m hoping to start offering private AAT services with my certified pup.

comments.text: You are always a therapist providing therapy with a code appropriate to your treatment. You just happen to use an animal as a mode to deliver it. They stress this in my hippotherapy certification classes.

I have a facility dog that works with me in a hospital based outpatient setting.  We bill for whatever we are working on, balance, gait, coordination, etc and consider the animal a tool to work on those things.

post_text:
**Remember what it was like when you started grad school?**

There was excitement.  Passion. Dreams existed.

If you were like me, you felt like a young kid again. 

Nervous as heck walking into class that first day knowing absolutely NO ONE.

But I knew that my journey was starting right then and there; on that day.

As we move along in our journeys, The System sucks all of that positive-ness and hope right out of us.

We conform to the expected norm.  Burnout prevails. 

The Establishment doesn't care.  Thousands of new clinicians are knocking on the door each year.

The best in you has served its purpose.

**George Bernard Shaw** said it best:

*"We don't quit playing because we grow old. We grow old because we quit playing."*

In 2020, 22K - as in 22,000 - of us quit playing.  Many because of burnout.

You ***can*** bring the playground back into your own life, and have fun doing it.

**Are you ready to feel like a kid again and build not only a business, but also a life that is *UNCAGED*?**

We are releasing the next **UNCAGED Business Launchpad** this **Wednesday, Oct 11**

Come play with us.

And build those dreams you once had.  And feel like a kid again.

Comment **"Dreams"** below to get all of the details.

post_text: Best advice for soccer cleat fitting? Any key points? Patient with plantar fasciitis.

comments.text: Don't go cheap. There are literally zero support in those. Some of the higher end shoes have much better support on the bottom and in the inserts.

The stud pattern can make a big difference. Soft ground for wet fields, AG or round studs for turf. 

If they need wide fit, new balance usually has more options. Every brand will have several models that fit differently. Some insoles are really cheaply designed even on the high end cleats.

full_thread_text:
POST: Best advice for soccer cleat fitting? Any key points? Patient with plantar fasciitis.

COMMENT 1: Don't go cheap. There are literally zero support in those. Some of the higher end shoes have much better support on the bottom and in the inserts.

COMMENT 2: The stud pattern can make a big difference. Soft ground for wet fields, AG or round studs for turf. 

If they need wide fit, new balance usually has more options. Every brand will have several models that fit differently. Some insoles are really cheaply designed even on the high end cleats.

If your a therapist, You MUST read  this book & read this chapter first (in the pic) to see the profound correlationsï¿¼ between ethical fading in all areas of business and the REHAB world. 

I will share public on my personal business page if you want to share! 

I summarized the chapter below putting all my (therapy correlations in parentheses)

CHAPTER 8: Ethical fading:ï¿¼ When structure replaces leadership

-the infinite game means to run a business with no end goal, just help advance humanity and help people. 
-The finite game means to run a business always looking to win, reach a goal, quota, number, productivity percentageï¿¼
-if ethical fading can happen where integrity is taken really seriously, like the military, then it can happen anywhere! And it does! 
-if you Create processes, check boxes, quotas or productivity percentages to be reached, they will always will tell us what we want to hear, but it may not be telling us the truth
-when leaders choose to implement processes and demands (like productivity rather than clinical judgment), The opportunity for systemic ethical fading persist, especially if these demands are not only unreasonable but are OUTRIGHT impossible. 
-pressure comes from the top down (director of rehab telling you what to do) but also pressure comes from the bottom up (in an effort to stand out, new grads/those looking for a raise/brown nosers want to appear they can do everything, so they work off the clock or provide fraudulent therapy to reach productivity) and a failure to do these bad things makes others look bad. Submitting a false report helps the system run smoothly and keeps their careers on track. Because the punishment for being honest is greater than for Lies, (therapist) feel they have to lie or cheat to meet the requirements placed upon them. Itâ€™s a catch 22. They will do this while believing that their high moral standards have remained uncompromised. They donâ€™t see this as unethical or lying, they see it as part of the bureaucratic process of checking the boxes, just doing what leader ship wanted them to do. 
-When these seemingly minor transgressions become pervasive in a culture, it is a sign of ethical fading!
-the irony is that when we apply finite related solutions to address a problem of ethical fading, that finite minded thinking created, we get more ethical fading. When we use processes and structure to fix cultural problems, we get more lying and cheating, then the behavior becomes normalized. 
-calling someone a lazy leader is not calling them a bad person just like calling someone a lazy person who doesnâ€™t want to exercise doesnâ€™t mean theyâ€™re a bad person. Their decisions are often very well intended. They actually believe these demands are going to be helpful but because leadership never experiences these demands theyâ€™re oblivious to the problems they create. 
-More structure is not the answer! 
-ethical fading  is a People problem and we need PEOPLE to correct a People problem
-THE ANSWER is an infinite mind set
-leaders who give their staff a just cause to advance, and give them a trusting TEAM, Will build a culture in which their people can work toward the STG while staying ethical, NOT because they are told to, NOT because they have a checklist that requires it, NOT because they took the companies online course, they did it because itâ€™s the natural human thing to do. 
-my inputâ€¦
-leadership should let their SNF therapists know that if they let their productivity dip below 90% because it was ethically correct to take time to talk to a family member or doctor which is non-productive time, the company may not have enough money to support raises or other employee request this year but if they also support the just cause of â€œ letâ€™s help our seniors age in place and keep them as mobile and healthy as we possibly canâ€ by selling more 1:1 gym training or wellness programs, we can fund more employee request! Now if your higher ups and COEs are making millions or billions, THATS A WHOLE OTHER ISSUE!

Iâ€™m starting to wonder if people are ignoring their ï¿¼ moral compass

post_text:
Okay, so, real talk. I'm feeling defeated, desperate and overwhelmed with the therapy world and really want to dive into this thing - but I'm terrified.

I am currently 26 weeks pregnant and my husband was recently traumatically injured in a work accident on 4/26/23 where he will be off work for an extended time (he lost 2 fingers and will need multiple surgeries for his two remaining).

In your opinion, is this feasible given my circumstances to dive in now? Or, would you wait until after baby is here? Just needing some real life advice I guess. I know there are many contingencies.

comments.text: Iâ€™m sorry to hear of your husbandâ€™s accident. Maybe this is not the time to dive into a new project or make big changes or decisions, take care of yourself and your baby, help your husband and revisit the concept of job or career changes after you recover from childbirth

No question for me, wait! Get settled in new baby world, let someone pay some maternity leave as you set up your business. Also, don't let crazy pregnancy hormones rule your decisions or how you interact with your new clients. What if you go 10 weeks early? What would you do, you aren't set up, etc. Get excited and planned...that's my real world advice. Life will be challenging for the next few months, after that, dive in. While there's no perfect time, this doesn't seem like anywhere close to the right time based on the info you provided.

I only post these things not to brag because my success has been minimal compared to most, but itâ€™s just so I can hopefully help other people drop the imposter syndrome that I was holding onto for a while and realize that there are people out there that really value what we do. 

I just had a self-pay patient give me a $20 tip randomly. I charged this person $130 for a 45 min visit and they gave me a tip. 

This wasnâ€™t coming from an extremely wealthy person. From what I can tell they arenâ€™t struggling, but life isnâ€™t easy peasy. So for them to value my service so much that they were like, you know what, youâ€™re worth more, was a little eye opening. 

I asked if they were sure they didnâ€™t want change. 

The patientâ€™s response: Donâ€™t worry about the change. You deserve a tip. Youâ€™re worth every penny. Iâ€™m so glad that I found you!

Yaâ€™llâ€¦ this kind of blew my mind a bit. 

EVERYONE, PLEASE donâ€™t under value yourself! 

It doesnâ€™t matter what this insurance or that thinks we are worth. It doesnâ€™t matter what Johnny PT Mill down the road or the other PP PT clinic close by sets their prices at.

Set your price and deliver quality care. People will recognize the difference and the word will spread. Let the mills do their mill thing while you take the time to have real life changing results with your people.

comments.text: I had a patientâ€™s daughter take me out to lunch todayâ€¦. Quite $$ and pay me my visit rate to discuss how her mom is doing and what her needs might be. Yes. These people exist. Itâ€™s amazing when you get out of the insanity how clear that becomes.
This is awesome. Iâ€™m launching this week and really struggling with feeling that imposter syndrome. Thanks for the encouragement.

Kindof silly question coming at you all: writing articles.

Are we just brain dumping on a particular subject?  Are these long articles, or just a few paragraphs?  Are we doing research specifically for the article, or are they more anecdotal based on our experience and knowledge?  Are these just sort of blog posts that we're calling articles?  How are we "publishing" them?

I'm feeling stuck on writing anything, because I feel like there must be some "rules" but maybe I'm just limiting myself for no reason other than imposter syndrome.

comments.text:

You can write about anything, but there's some ways to tailor it to where you're posting the writing....
You can write anything you want in any way that you feel will be helpful for your target audience.

post_text:
I got a beautiful gift from my mom for Christmas. She doesn't listen to the Uncaged Clinician podcast, so she had no idea HOW significant this was to me.

One of my absolute favorite episodes is called Anchoring to Your Purpose. Around the 7:40 mark, Kevin DeGroot shares an analogy of the uphill climb on a bicycle, comparing that feeling to business ownership and pointing out why it's not the same at all.

There is no coasting downhill for us. Leaders are *always* climbing.

If you are incapable of looking around you and enjoying/appreciating that climb, then maybe what you're actually doing is chasing.

Chasing a certain account balance. Recognition. Spousal approval. Self validation.

If you're chasing, consider what it might be like to not need to chase anymore.

If you're climbing, keep climbing.

Shout out to Nate Navas for keeping this podcast going for the past 4 years, effectively creating a library of invaluable content.

This is so beautiful

post_text:
You got into this profession for a reason. It wasn't easy to get through school. It wasn't easy to make the sacrifices that you made but you still did it for a reason. 

Then you got jaded. A bad boss, frustrating work experience, etc put you in a position that you felt burnt out. 

Now you're searching for how to fix the burn out and you're incessantly marketed to that MONEY is going to solve your problem. 

It won't.

It might be a salve on the pain for a bit but that isn't going to get you back to why you did what you did in the first place. Why you made all the sacrifices and did all the work. 

Businesses should be created so you can reengage with the why and passion you had for loving, serving, caring for and leading other in the first place. Not so you can get over your jaded attitude by making more money.

post_text: Hi. Curious how you calculate vacation and sick time into your scheduling/paying yourselves? Iâ€™ve got 3 littles at home so getting sick is inevitable

comments.text: Iâ€™ve never calculated it at all. I feel like thatâ€™s the beauty of paying yourself. If you have to â€œcall in sickâ€, itâ€™s only to yourself. My patients all know I have 3 kids, and I am as up front as possible with them regarding potentials for me not being available (school holidays, days off for storms, someone in the house not feeling well, etc). Iâ€™ve never had anyone push back on me needing to reschedule because of a kid thing. And as far as paying myself, I pay myself what I would have if I worked.

I use a variation of the profit first model. I read most if it and then stopped once I had the general idea so itâ€™s not not necessarily the exact method. It is based off of percentages of the money coming in going into different accounts. The â€œprofitâ€ account I think of as a mini savings account that I pay myself a bonus from quarterly. I will dip into it sooner if I have a slower pay period. 
I inevitably need to cancel folks like last Friday when my youngest was sick I rescheduled what I could and stayed home to snuggle my munchkin. 
I also have much less guilt then when I worked for a big clinic who would try and reschedule my caseload onto my already overwhelmed coworkers. Now I call my patients and they say absolutely take care of your daughter please tell her I hope she feels better.

post_text: I am in the process of starting my own mobile practice. I will be the only employee. Are there others like me on this group? If so, any advice would be appreciated!

comments.text: ðŸ™‹â€â™€ï¸ you are going to get a lot of really great advice from a therapy perspective and a therapy business perspective on this page. I also work with a SCORE mentor (it's a free program across the country that links you up with someone in your city who can mentor you for starting a small business). I have found it really helpful for non-therapy, but state specific stuff. They will help you write a business plan, they will look at your books to help you figure out where to be more profitable. They will teach you where free resources are (like market analyses on the local library website). Mine happened to have mentored another OT in the past, so I was able to connect with others to network. It's been very beneficial along with the great support from the mentors here!

Me!  Been on my own for two years now and I havenâ€™t regretted one second of it. I say use groups like this to get ideas but make sure you do your own research as well. Some well meaning people may give wrong info or things that maybe only pertain to their state etcâ€¦
Good luck!

post_text:
As Iâ€™ve made more money and been around people who make a lot of money I feel itâ€™s important to remind people that the people who make a ton of money have the same core problems you do. Yet so often we chase money as though itâ€™ll fix root issues in our mindset, families, friendships, health, faith, etc 

Please donâ€™t fall victim to that belief.

comments.text: Dropping bombs ðŸ’£

Bravo. I cringe occasionally at the â€œprosperity gospelâ€ messaging I see in this group, and others, online. And I would like to add a perspective â€œfrom the other sideâ€ if you will: after working in the PT industry for years, in the 90s i had gone back to school for a post-professional doctorate and opened a private practice. Huge success, dreams coming true left and right, then in spring 2001 my life partner was diagnosed with cancer. He died two weeks after 9/11. And suddenly none of that success meant anything. There was NO amount of money that could have kept him with me, and I would have paid ANY amount of money for just 5 more minutes. And not a single minute of all of those weeks, months, years of spending 50,60,70+ hours/week working, studying, away from home could be reclaimed. I was 38yo! Please be mindful about what you wish for. Honor the sacrifices you (and by default your loved ones) are making to achieve your wishes. And make choices so that you have no regrets laterâ€¦no matter the outcome.

post_text:
Almost all of us have thoughts of â€œWhat would happen if I had to miss extensive work to take care of my family?â€

The unfortunate reality is that very few jobs afford one the time or the ability to be absent for prolonged periods.

Such a situation typically would require the employee to exhaust their PTO (paid time off).

But, what if there is no PTO to take?  Or, what if there is enough to cover only a couple of days?

This can create quite the dilemma and a lot of stress, particularly if that person is the primary caretaker.

I.S. is dealing with this challenge today.

Her daughter and her husband are both battling COVID.  Her husband is rather ill.

Thatâ€™s not all.  I.S.â€™s mother has been diagnosed with stage I cancer.  Her father is not in a position to care for her mom.

Thus, tending to the needs of three family members falls on I.S.

Having to care for her own immediate family consumes enough of her time.  Caring for her mother who is attending various appointments for her cancer is a huge heaping pile on top of it all.

It is pretty easy to see how I.S. could be stretched beyond too thin; particularly with a job that shows little empathy for her situation, and demands that she give her time to work.

How would you handle this?

Would you be frazzled? Stressed? Mad? Resentful? 

Probably so.

You know how I.S feels?

Sheâ€™s grateful.

Thatâ€™s right. Grateful.

Why?

After sharing the details of her current situation, I.S. concluded with this statement:

â€œ*Thank God I have my own business so that I can have the time to take care of everyone*.â€

She makes the rules.

Furthermore, she has attracted a clientele who serves *her*.  They do so in two ways.

First, her clients are who she enjoys helping.  Working with them is fun for her.  She doesnâ€™t view her business as â€œbeing workâ€.

Secondly, they serve her by understanding that family comes first.  They are supportive of her during this time.

In other words, her clients fill *her* cup.

Wouldnâ€™t it be fantawesome if we all could be so lucky as to have clients like I.S.â€™s?!

Guess what?

We - and *YOU* - can.

The only thing standing in the way of this utopia being a reality is you making the decision to make it happen.

And, you can.

Do you want to be able to create your own job where you can have the same time freedom and flexibility as I.S?

Do you want to work with clients who serve *you* rather than giving of yourself to your limits for seeminglyâ€¦ nothing?

We are here to help you to get started.

YOU having the control begins by clicking on the link in the comments below. ðŸ‘‡

Got 2 networking folks email me back agreeing to meet up!! But now I have a problem, as I work 830-530 M-F in a clinic. One of them would like to meet and come in to watch a laser treatment thing. 

Does anyone have advice about working around my current work schedule? I'm not allowed to just take one hour off work, I'd have to take off half day and I don't have PTO to use for that, nor will have availability to request off for at least a month. Any suggestions that have worked for others in the past who are working full time still? Idk for sure, but doubt the physician works Saturdays.

Please help this good problem to have!

comments.text:
Did I hear you are going to be sick that day, specifically at ___ oâ€™clock. ? ðŸ˜‚

In all seriousness, as a clinic owner now I would let me staff take an as much time as they need and make it up another day etc. 

When I was a full time employee I asked my DOR if I could take an extended lunch/come in later/leave earlier because I have ______   I was never denied. It wouldnâ€™t hurt to ask even if it is a policy.

Maybe try telling the physician that you don't have any availability during the week for the next month or so then ask if Saturdays work for them at all. I switched to PRN inpatient so that I could work until I was done vs a set schedule. It definitely helped during the transition period.

 -Each of us has a history of wins, lessons, trials, tribulations, successes and seeming failures. Each of these has a voice that comes with them that competes for our attention. Which voice is loudest to you and what does that mean towards you progressing towards your goals?

 - Weâ€™ve all been told that having boundaries is important but how do you understand the tension between boundaries and the calling to love, serve, care and lead?

 - what is the process we need to go to become more resilient people and leaders? 

Week 6. Stand and Lead
 - What do you stand for? What do you aspire to be as a leader?
